div.p: This paper is aimed to analyze and control the structure vibration of a vehicle steering wheel by using the acceleration transfer path analysis (TPA) method and vibration sensitivity method. A steering wheel vibration test is conducted to obtain the critical engine speed and corresponding to the frequency. The acceleration-acceleration transfer function from mounts body side to steering wheel is deducted and tested, in conjunction with the actual acceleration spectrums of mounts body side, the acceleration spectrum of steering wheel is synthesized and the accuracy of the synthetic results is evaluated high. Then the vibration transmitted by each path is investigated and the main vibration participation paths are picked out from numerous paths. The interaction mechanisms between the path transfer vibration, path vibration participation and the total vibration are further obtained. The critical parameters (mounting stiffnesses and vibration sensitivity) of the main vibration participation paths are matched, modified and the vibration control effect is experimental verified. The results indicate that, by pertinently matching the stiffness parameters of the mounts and reducing vibration sensitivity of structure, the dynamic force transmitted by the paths are decreased, the vibration transfer functions from mounts body side to steering wheel are decreased, and then the actual steering wheel vibration is controlled.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The trimbody (TB) structure are vulnerable to vibrate (especially the steering wheel of TB), when the exciting frequency of engine or road is close to the natural frequencies of powertrain rigid mode, steering wheel elastic mode or suspension elastic mode. If the steering wheel structure vibration perceived by passengers, it will affect the vehicle NVH performance seriously. Thus, it is an important and meaningful task for engineers to control the vibration of steering wheel structures to design high quality products.

The underlying physics governing of this dynamic behavior (steering wheel vibration) can be represented by the excitation characteristics (such as engine dynamic load or road dynamic load) [1] and in conjunction with vibration transfer function (VTF) [2] (also known as vibration sensitivity). In analyzing the VTFs for steering wheel structures, which is a low frequency vibration (frequency less than 60Hz) problem, the applications of numerical analytical method [3] (Multi-body Dynamics Model or Finite Element Model) or experimental test method (such as Hammer Transmission Experiment) are often employed [4] .

In order to control the vibration of structures, a transfer path analysis (TPA, also known as Classical TPA) [5] or a modified TPA (e.g. Operational TPA, Component-based TPA) [6] method are employed recently. TPA reveals the physical essence of the relationship between excitation source, transfer path and receiver. By using a TPA technology, the source excitations can be separated from the structural/acoustic transfer characteristics, allowing us to troubleshoot the dominant paths of vibration transmission. The engineer can then anticipate by making changes to either the source itself or the receiving structures that are connected to it [7] . Due to these advantages, TPA tends to be particularly associated with noise, vibration and harshness (NVH) engineering as commonly encountered in the automotive industry, although TPA having been developed mostly during the second half of the 20th century. The literatures on this aspect are voluminous, and we have compiled a selective to provide background information and useful cross-references on the subject. In the field of TPA, literatures [4,[7][8][9][10][11][12] explained the general framework: history, theory and the classification of techniques, which was a useful asset to help understanding the countless possibilities and combinations within the TPA paradigm. The transfer matrix method (or modified transfer matrix method) in conjunction with experimental technique have been developed for analyzing and controlling the vibration and noise transmission of engineering structure, such as the study of the effect of structure-borne or air-borne paths induced interfering noise of a vehicle cab (e.g. braking noise [13] ,road noise [8,14,15] , acceleration noise [16] , sound quality [17] ). With the two time-domain TPA models, Liu [2] found that the models can predict the transient vibration in the door slamming event and the contribution of each transfer path was obtained. Based on the transmissibility concept, Cervantes [18] investigated the design and implementation of a simplified method, which allows a rapid and accurate analysis. By using the power flow analysis and acoustic path participation method, literatures [19] obtained the high energy transfer paths and the dynamic parameters of these paths being modified to reduce noise radiation. Although the TPA or modified TPA have been investigated theoretically (e.g. Refs [7,8,11] ) and applied to control the structure vibration (e.g. Refs [2,3] ), the theoretical calculation process is complex which needs to voluminous formula derivation, matrix inversion and interface force calculation, or there is no independent intellectual property right by using the existing TPA commercial software (such as LMS Test.Lab or HEAD acoustics). The literatures about rapid TPA (with these characteristics: theory and application convenient, having independent intellectual property rights) and in conjunction with the dynamic parameter matching of identified path on the basis of vibration sensitivity analysis are handful.

Steering wheel vibration is caused by the excitation characteristics and vibration transfer characteristics of each system. To achieve significant vibration reduction at the steering wheel, the critical paths and critical structures need to be identified and matched. The current paper is partly motivated by these investigations and carries out related research. The direct acceleration TPA method is proposed, deducted, verified and applied to identify critical paths, and then the vibration sensitivity is investigated to modify critical structures. The remainder will be organized as follows. Section 2 will theoretically deduce the vibration sensitivity method and acceleration TPA method; Section 3 describes an engineering case application (steering wheel vibration); Acceleration TPA method will be applied to investigate steering wheel vibration and obtain the critical vibration participation paths in Section 4; The vibration sensitivity analysis will be conducted and structural parameters will be modified to control steering wheel vibration in Section 5; Section 6 draws some concluding remarks.

div.head: Engineering case study
div.p: During the slow acceleration of a four stroke four cylinder engine vehicle, the steering wheel vibration is serious within the 1000 rpm -1300rpm speed range, which is shown in Fig. 4. The Y-labels in the Fig. 4 is in a dB form, and the relationship between acceleration and dB is expressed as, in which the reference acceleration a0=1m/s 2 .

1800 9001000 1100 1200 1300 1400 1500 1600 rpm 0 - It can be found from Fig. 4 that the vibration acceleration curve of steering wheel exists two large peaks, -2.7dB@1050rpm and -1.8dB@1250rpm respectively. The second-order vibration is the main contribution, which are -3.0dB@1050rpm and -2.3dB@1250rpm respectively. According to the formulation in literature [1] and in conjunction with the excitation characteristics of a four stroke four cylinder engine, the critical frequencies corresponding to the two peaks are 35Hz and 41.7Hz respectively.

div.head: Critical vibration paths identification
div.p: Because of the high accuracy of acceleration TPA method, the Eq.( 9) can be used to further investigate the vibration transmitted by each path. The vibration accelerations transferred by the 9 paths are shown in Fig. 9. It can be known from Fig. 9 that the paths P3, P6 and P7 (i.e. Z direction of left mount, Z direction of right mount and X direction of low rod) transfer vibration to the Z direction of steering wheel 12 o'clock significantly, which are -14.3dB(35Hz), -13.2dB(35Hz) and -9.5dB(35Hz) (i.e. 0.19m/s 2 , 0.22 m/s 2 , 0.34 m/s 2 ) respectively. And then, the major paths vibration transfer participation with respect to total synthetic vibration is shown in Fig. 10 and Table .1. Focusing on the results in Fig. 10 and Table .1, it is easy to obtain that the participations of the vibration transferred of the major paths (P3, P6 and P7) to the synthetic vibration are positive, which are 0.07m/s 2 , 0.21m/s 2 and 0.33m/s 2 respectively.

According to the theoretical method in Section 2.2, for the positive participation paths, the acceleration at Z direction of steering wheel 12 o'clock will decrease pronounced by reducing the vibration transmission of these main paths

Compared with the Classical TPA, Operational TPA or Component-based TPA [7][8][9][10] , the acceleration TPA method proposed in this paper is high accuracy, convenient in theory and application. Thus this is a novelty of this paper. On the basis of the acceleration TPA method, the critical paths are picked out from numerous paths and the vibration participation of paths are obtained, which is an useful information for instructing the engineers to modify the structure pertinently.

div.head: Structural parameters matching to control vibration
div.p: For the identified main paths, the stiffness parameters of powertrain mounts and structural parameters of steering wheel system will be matched and improved to control the vibration of steering wheel.

div.p: The paths P7, P6 and P3 are the main vibration participation paths, especially P7 and P6. div.p: ) from the interaction interfaces to steering wheel. The dynamic forces of the paths P7, P6 and P3 have been decreased in Section 5.1, here the vibration sensitivity corresponding to the main vibration participation paths will be controlled.

The tested and simulated vibration sensitivity of the paths P7 and P6 are shown in Fig. 14. Focusing on the results in Fig. 14, it is clear that the trends of simulated VTF(œâ) and tested VTF(œâ) are in good agreement, the amplitude error is small in the frequency band 25Hz to 40Hz. The peak values of tested VTF(œâ) are -18.4dB(33Hz) and -22.9dB(33Hz), the peak values of simulated VTF(œâ) are -20.7dB(35Hz) and -27.2dB(35Hz). Thus, the critical frequency of simulated and tested agrees well, and that of peak amplitude also agrees well. In view of this, the accuracy of this simulation model is high and the structural modification scheme made by this FEM model can predict the vibration sensitivity effectively. In order to reduce the vibration sensitivity of the main vibration participation paths around 35Hz, the IPI(œâ) parameters of Node 10 are crucial (see Fig. 15).Thus, with the help of FEM(TB + Powertrain) model, the X direction, Z direction and Ry direction IPI simulation analysis of the node 10 are carried out, and the results are given in Fig. 16. It can be seen from Fig. 16 that the X direction, Z direction and Ry direction IPI values are 124.2mm/s 2 /N(34Hz), 43.7mm/s 2 /N(34Hz) and 3.6¬∞/(Nm)(35Hz), respectively. To decrease IPI(œâ) in X direction, a triangular support is adopt to vertically connect the transverse pipe beam and the front wall structure (see modified position‚ë†in Fig. 17). The thickness of transverse pipe beam is increased from 1.6mm to 2mm (see modified position‚ë°in Fig. 17) to decrease IPI(œâ) in Z direction. A support plate is added at the left end face of the transverse pipe beam and the distance between bolt holes (see modified position‚ë¢ and partial enlarged view in Fig. 17) is increased to decrease IPI(œâ) in Ry direction. The results of IPI analysis of the modified steering wheel structure are given in Fig. 16. It can be found from Fig. 16 that the X direction, Z direction and Ry direction IPI values are 85.5 mm/s 2 /N(34Hz), 26.7mm/s 2 /N(34Hz) and 1.3¬∞/Nm(35Hz), respectively (i.e. decreased 31%, 39% and 64% ). The simulated and tested VTF(œâ) results of the main vibration participation paths after structure modification are shown in Fig. 18 and Fig. 19. It can be known from Fig. 18 that, the vibration sensitivity (i.e. VTF(œâ)) of path P6 and P7 are reduced by 6.2dB(35Hz) and 8.0dB(35Hz), respectively. Focusing on the tested results in Fig. 19, the vibration sensitivity of path P6 and P7 are reduced by 9.2dB(33Hz) and 11.0dB(33Hz), respectively. Based on the theory of Section 2.1 and engineering application of Sections 5.1 and 5.2, the vibration sensitivity analysis (VTF (translational motion sensitivity or rotational motion sensitivity) and IPI) used in this paper is effective, targeted and the control effect of the improved scheme on vehicle vibration is evaluated in an early phase. This is another novelty of this paper.

div.head: Experimental verification
div.p: The improved scheme for slow acceleration steering wheel vibration is verified on the whole vehicle, and the comprehensive experimental verification of Case 1 in Sections 5.1 and Case 2 in Sections 5.2 denotes Opt. The test results are provided in Fig. 20. It is obvious to find from Fig. 20 that, during vehicle slow acceleration, the steering wheel vibration decreases seriously in the engine speed range 1000rpm-1250rpm. The overall vibration and 2 order vibration of steering wheel are reduced by 7.9dB@1050rpm (i.e. from -2.7dB to -10.6dB) and 9.0dB@1050rpm (i.e. from -3.0dB to -12.0dB) respectively. Thus, the effectiveness of acceleration TPA method, vibration sensitivity analysis method and targeted reduction of structure vibration are verified by experiments.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, the structural vibration analysis and control are conducted by employing the acceleration TPA method and vibration sensitivity method. The acceleration TPA analysis is adopted to achieve the vibration transmitted by each path, vibration participation of path and identify the critical vibration participation paths. Then, the force transfer sensitivity and vibration transfer sensitivity of these critical paths are investigated, the mounts stiffness parameters matching and structural improvement are further studied to reduce steering wheel vibration pertinently and effectively. Based on the above analysis, the following conclusions could be derived:

(1) The acceleration TPA method proposed in this paper is convenient in theory and application, having independent intellectual property right. On the basis of the acceleration TPA method, the steering wheel vibration can be well predicted and investigated.

(2) For different vibration transfer paths, the vibration participation of paths with respect to total vibration is different and the relationship between path transmitted vibration, path vibration participation and total vibration are derived. The value of vibration participation can be positive or negative which is determined by the angle between path transmitted vibration and total vibration.

(3) The vibration sensitivity analysis used in this paper is convenient, effective and targeted. By matching the mounts stiffness parameters corresponding to the critical path, the force transfer functions of these path decrease evidently. By modifying the steering wheel structure (triangular support, pipe thickness, support plate and bolt hole distance), the values of IPI(œâ) decreased significantly, and the VTF(œâ) results of the main vibration participation paths reduce by more than 6dB. The vehicle verification shows that the steering wheel vibration is reduced by more than 8dB.

The acceleration TPA method in conjunction with the vibration sensitivity method proposed in this paper can be used to analyze and control the vibration of complex engineering structure pertinently and effectively. The advantage is particularly obvious when engineering structure is imposed complex excitations and has many vibration transfer paths.
